instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00926: What is 820-00926? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.820-00928: What is 820-00928? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00926</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Has circle with line through it. And spots that look like dead pixels.
threads.message: This board had slight liquid damage in the CPU circuit area. <SIGNAL>PPBUS_HS_CPU</SIGNAL> had a damaged capacitor. No short though. The board will try to boot (seems intermittent) and will show the Apple for a second and then show a circle with a line through it. At the same time, a bunch of random pixels will light up. The pixels change each time I try to boot. It looks like about 25 dead pixels spread randomly around the screen. Nothing else happening. I haven't seen anything like this before. Not sure where to go next.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00926</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Has circle with line through it. And spots that look like dead pixels.
threads.message: Sounds like a nice dead CPU to me lmao 12? are so bad

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00926</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Has circle with line through it. And spots that look like dead pixels.
threads.message:
Yeah, thanks, seems to be the case. I'm hoping for some other magic fix being that the CPU is at least doing something.

Also, I had the number wrong. It's <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>. 2017 MacBook Pro 15". Is someone able to fix the title for me? Not sure if it will matter as far as the outcome but it would be nice to at least get that part right.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00926</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Has circle with line through it. And spots that look like dead pixels.
threads.message:
If 15", then could be GPU, or vRAM issue.
Disconnect internal LCD and test with external monitor.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00926</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Has circle with line through it. And spots that look like dead pixels.
threads.message: Yeah same as 2informaticos said. Usually, liquid by VCore area on newer ones is a nightmare

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00926</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Has circle with line through it. And spots that look like dead pixels.
threads.message: Yes, it displays the exact same thing on an external screen. Weirdly, before I replaced <CAPACITOR>C7292</CAPACITOR> it would just hang on the Apple, but not show the circle symbol. Is there any type of fix I might be able to try or is this just done?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00926</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Has circle with line through it. And spots that look like dead pixels.
threads.message: [USER="682"]2informaticos[/USER] Any last words for this one? Any hope?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00926</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Has circle with line through it. And spots that look like dead pixels.
threads.message:
<CAPACITOR>C7292</CAPACITOR> has nothing to do with this issue; is not really needed.
Something happened when you applied heat on that area.
Check for corrosion under microscope.
Put good flux and heat GPU, <CHIP>U9800</CHIP> and CPU; no more than 180-200 degrees, just to burn eventually crap underneath.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00926</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Has circle with line through it. And spots that look like dead pixels.
threads.message: Ok, thanks, I'll try that. I purposely only used a soldering iron to avoid adding heat. No heat gun. The whole replacement was done in a matter of seconds. <CAPACITOR>C7292</CAPACITOR> was already falling off the board so it was straightforward. I'll try to clean up those area with some flux and see if that helps.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00926</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Has circle with line through it. And spots that look like dead pixels.
threads.message: I checked the board again. I attached a pre-cleaning picture of the area hit (and then pictures of the whole board, also pre-cleaning). This is the only area that was hit by the spill. Underneath that corrosion, the only components that look damaged were a few smaller capacitors. I replaced <CAPACITOR>C7292</CAPACITOR>, and <CAPACITOR>C7290</CAPACITOR> and <CAPACITOR>C7293</CAPACITOR> look a little rough but are measuring fine. Is there a chance that one of these might be failing once power is applied? I've never know this to happen but I'm wondering if a capacitor could fail in this way, where it's intermittently shorting or partially shorting? I just can't find any other reason why this board is failing.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00926</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Has circle with line through it. And spots that look like dead pixels.
threads.message:
None of these caps are related with your issue.
You can just let them out of board.

Dead pixels spread around the screen, even on external monitor, point to GPU, or vRAM problem.
But prohibition sign should be something else.
Disconnect Lifeboat connector and try to start USB OSX.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00926</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Has circle with line through it. And spots that look like dead pixels.
threads.message: It's a 2018 so no lifeboat. It's also booting, or attempting to boot, intermittently now, so sometimes I can't get it to the drive-select screen. And sometimes it seems to freeze. I'm not getting to the prohibition sign much anymore. I guess the assumption is that the CPU or VRAM was damaged from the spill even though it didn't hit the CPU or VRAM directly? It's completely clean around all of that.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00926</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Has circle with line through it. And spots that look like dead pixels.
threads.message:
"It's <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>. 2017 MacBook Pro 15""
I saw J9600 on your photos, near PCH...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00926</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Has circle with line through it. And spots that look like dead pixels.
threads.message: You're right. I'm confused. I had a 2018 sitting in front of me when I was typing that. Letting this one go. So little liquid-damage for such a complete failure.
